Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: S2I2: Conceptualization of a Center for Biomolecular Simulation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support the planning for a scientific software Institute in the area of computational chemistry. Molecular simulation is an integral part of contemporary chemistry due to its broad adoption by academic researchers and industries that use molecular mechanics and dynamics methodology to advance their science. The major molecular software programs have been downloaded by every major research university and biotech and pharmaceutical companies, and their wide usage is well exemplified by the ~30% of awarded cycles on the NSF XSEDE platforms. However, development, testing, and validation of biomolecular simulation software, and the realization of high-throughput production runs made available on various hardware architectures, is something that the user community wants and requires, but is not something that has been adequately supported in a sustained way in the academic environment.

The planning meetings will enable invaluable graduate training by inviting local graduate students in the computational sciences and provide them an opportunity to understand the landscape of research opportunities at the interface of cyberinfrastructure and biomolecular sciences. The second workshop will examine education, outreach and training opportunities that an Institute of such scale and scope provides. The blueprint for the Institute will highlight multiple inter-disciplinary research problems and agenda; collectively, this will contribute to the training of the next-generation computational scientists and application-oriented cyberinfrastructure experts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Molecular simulation is an integral part of contemporary biochemistry due to its broad adoption by academic researchers and industries that use molecular mechanics and statistical sampling methodology to advance their science. The major molecular mechanics software programs such as Amber, CHARMM, DLPOLY, GROMACS, LAMMPS, NAMD, and TINKER have been downloaded by every major research university and many biotech and pharmaceutical companies, and their wide usage is well exemplified by the ∼30% of awarded cycles on the NSF XSEDE platforms. These compute cycles are devoted to first the generation and subsequently the analysis of a large set of sample statistics, typically collected over long timescales using molecular dynamics, on condensed phase systems which have a large numbers of degrees of freedom. Indeed, although molecular simulations account for a significant fraction of all compute cycles in computational chemistry, the community software is distributed over a highly heterogeneous and fractured cyberinfrastructure environment, limiting sustainability and research productivity for broader scientific missions that occur at the interface of simulation communities. The conceptualization awards are part of the NSF-S2I2 program to develop scientific and software priorities through community workshops to establish new Software Institutes, and our efforts are focused in the areas of chemistry, biochemistry, and materials.

What a molecular simulation software institute could bring to the computational chemistry community are the resources to advance new software initiatives. These software-related initiatives are the enablers for bridging and interfacing different simulation communities to do a new level of science grand challenge problem not currently achievable within more specialized communities, and to do so on a more sustained time scale not possible before. To achieve these objectives, this software institute conceptualization project for molecular simulation was organized into two workshops with multiple working groups – chosen in order to provide a balanced distribution of effort across application and science domains, existing community code development teams, and software best practice and sustainability, in order to enable sufficient coverage of the primary issues. The first workshop held in Berkeley was organized around community: the developers and users of molecular simulations codes, broadly defined (biomolecular science, chemical sciences, materials science), the SSEs and SSIs, and catalogued existing tools and frameworks and how they can be improved, and what are the gaps and missing capabilities that could be delivered by a molecular simulation Software Institute. The primary benefit to the simulation community for participation in this event is the exciting discussion around the scientific vision that can be realized with a new molecular simulation software institute. The second workshop held in Houston was responsible for the overall prioritization of cyberinfrastructure approaches that could be used to meet the required capabilities that are currently missing, including software frameworks and tools, code interoperability, data management, middleware and workflows, and current and emerging hardware paradigms. This also includes the academic community engagement with overall training and education goals in molecular simulation. The final project took the outcomes of the previous two workshops and combined it synergistically with another quantum chemistry conceptualization project to develop a proposal for a molecular simulation institute for computational chemistry. The final project provided the concrete vision of long term sustainability of quantum and statistical mechanical software used in broad application areas of molecular simulation, to service the grand challenge scientific discovery process in the chemical, biochemical, and material science communities, and was well-received in the simulation community.
